{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3325409,"name":"Adam Pullen","username":"Adam_6877","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adam_6877/{size}/196524_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-06T05:21:40.289Z","cooked":"

I am programming an arm powered by a neo 550 with a 100:1 gearbox on either side.

In theory: When a button is held, the two motors should smoothly run in opposite directions until the arm reaches the second setpoint (120°). When the button is released, the arm should smoothly go back down to (0°).

Problem: For whatever reason, the right motor seems to be correlated to the left and spins in the same direction (even when I don’t think the right motor is supposed to be running at all)

By the way, I put the two motors for the arm in separate subsystems as a last ditch effort to find the problem.

Thanks for your help!

Adam_6877:

By the way, I put the two motors for the arm in separate subsystems as a last ditch effort to find the problem.

I’d undo this. They’re the same subsystem since they’re mechanically linked by the arm itself. They should both be running, but one should be “following” the other.

Does .setinversed work on a follower?

Because it didn’t seem to.

Regardless, I’ll put the two motors in the same subsystem the way they should be.

it does not, but there is a second argument (inverted) that you can pass into the .follow() call which does work.

Docs: CANSparkBase (FRC-REVLib API)

Not quite. setInverted doesn’t work on followers. You have to pass true as the second argument of follow.
